sentences.text: Parliamentary elections were held in Iceland on 30 November 2024 to elect the 63 members of the Althing. The Centre-left politics|centre-left Social Democratic Alliance, led by Kristrún Frostadóttir, outperformed the ruling Independence Party (Iceland)|Independence Party to win the most seats, at 15. The election saw the worst performance by the Independence Party (Iceland)|Independence Party, Progressive Party (Iceland)|Progressive Party, the Left-Green Movement, and the Pirate Party (Iceland)|Pirate Party in each of the parties' histories, while Viðreisn, the People's Party (Iceland)|People's Party, and the Centre Party (Iceland)|Centre Party saw their best performance in each of the parties' histories. This follows a trend of Icelanders voting against every post–Great Recession|2008 recession government except during the 2021 Icelandic parliamentary election|2021 election.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://apnews.com/article/iceland-election-results-social-democrats-989773ec8a24cddef7ba78d5aa933df2 |title=Social democrats gain and incumbents are punished in Iceland’s election |date=1 December 2024 |access-date=1 December 2024 |website=Associated Press |language=en |archive-date=1 December 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241201150818/https://apnews.com/article/iceland-election-results-social-democrats-989773ec8a24cddef7ba78d5aa933df2 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20241201-social-democrats-set-to-overtake-ruling-party-in-iceland-snap-election |title=Social Democrats overtake PM's party in Iceland vote |date=1 December 2024 |access-date=1 December 2024 |website=France 24 |language=en |archive-date=1 December 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241201121640/https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20241201-social-democrats-set-to-overtake-ruling-party-in-iceland-snap-election |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The Left-Green Movement and the Pirate Party lost all of their parliamentary representation, with each failing to obtain a seat for the first time since their foundation in the 1999 Icelandic parliamentary election|1999 and 2013 Icelandic parliamentary election|2013 elections, respectively.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/1/social-democrats-win-icelands-snap-election-as-incumbents-punished |title=Social Democrats win Iceland’s snap elections as incumbents punished |date=1 December 2024 |access-date=2 December 2024 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: The coalition partners from the previous term soon decided that the first option for coalition talks should be to renew their coalition. The second cabinet of Katrín Jakobsdóttir was then formed on 28 November.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/icelands-left-right-coalition-agrees-take-another-term-2021-11-28/|title=Iceland's left-right coalition agrees to take another term|work=Reuters|date=28 November 2021|access-date=3 December 2021|archive-date=30 November 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211130052716/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/icelands-left-right-coalition-agrees-take-another-term-2021-11-28/|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |title=Katrin Jakobsdottir, Iceland's Staunch Feminist PM, Begins Second Term |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/katrin-jakobsdottir-iceland-staunch-feminist-pm-begins-second-term/6331139.html |date=28 November 2021 |work=Voice of America |access-date=15 December 2021 |archive-date=29 November 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211129092320/https://www.voanews.com/a/katrin-jakobsdottir-iceland-staunch-feminist-pm-begins-second-term/6331139.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: In April 2024, Katrín Jakobsdóttir resigned to contest the 2024 Icelandic presidential election, which she lost. She was succeeded as prime minister by Bjarni Benediktsson (born 1970)|Bjarni Benediktsson.

references.text: <ref name="collapse">{{cite news |date=13 October 2024 |title=Iceland PM calls new election as coalition government collapses |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/13/iceland-pm-calls-new-election-as-coalition-government-collapses |access-date=14 October 2024 |work=Al Jazeera |archive-date=10 November 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241110003614/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/13/iceland-pm-calls-new-election-as-coalition-government-collapses |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 13 October, prime minister Bjarni Benediktsson announced that the government had collapsed due to disputes over foreign policy, asylum seekers, and energy, prompting him to call for new elections and ask President Halla Tómasdóttir the next day to dissolve the Althingi and set the elections for 30 November. In particular, Bjarni cited "how different the Movement's vision for the future is, compared to what I want to stand for".

references.text: <ref name="collapse"/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://apnews.com/article/iceland-snap-election-coalition-government-9d170f37de3228506de93444668c416a |title=Iceland appears headed for a snap election after governing coalition collapses |work=Associated Press |date=14 October 2024 |access-date=14 October 2024 |archive-date=10 November 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241110003618/https://apnews.com/article/iceland-snap-election-coalition-government-9d170f37de3228506de93444668c416a |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="collapse new">{{cite web |url=https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/10/13/iceland-s-government-coalition-collapses-new-elections-to-be-held-in-november_6729282_4.html |title=Iceland's government coalition collapses, new elections to be held in November |work=Le Monde |date=13 October 2024 |access-date=14 October 2024 |archive-date=10 November 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241110003617/https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/10/13/iceland-s-government-coalition-collapses-new-elections-to-be-held-in-november_6729282_4.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: In November 2024, a Gallup, Inc.|Gallup poll found that more than 60% of voters regarded healthcare, economic issues and housing as a top concern. Immigration was regarded as a key issue by 32% of those surveyed while asylum issues accounted for 18% of respondents. The public broadcaster RÚV said that an AI chatbot set up to answer election-related questions received mostly queries on housing and taxation.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=30 November 2024 |title=Icelanders head to the polls after government collapse |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20241130-icelanders-head-to-the-polls-after-government-collapse |access-date=30 November 2024 |website=France 24 |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{further|Elections in Iceland}}
The 63 members of the Althing are elected by open list proportional representation in six multi-member Constituencies of Iceland|constituencies, with 54 seats allocated to parties at the constituency level with no electoral threshold, and 9 leveling seats assigned to party lists at the national level in order to ensure proportionality with the election result, with a threshold of 5 percent required. The 54 constituency seats are distributed within each constituency according to the D'Hondt method. Election lists are determined by parties; although voters have the option of altering the order of candidates or striking out particular candidates entirely, this rarely has any effect on the result.<ref name="OSCE"/>

references.text: <ref name="OSCE">{{cite report|title=Ísland, Alþingiskosningar, 27. April 2013: Úttektarskýrsla|url=http://www.osce.org/is/odihr/elections/iceland/103314?download=true|publisher=OSCE/ODIHR|date=24 June 2013|access-date=30 October 2017|archive-date=14 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160914235149/http://www.osce.org/is/odihr/elections/iceland/103314?download=true|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|title=Útreikningar við úthlutun jöfnunarsæta|url=http://www.kosning.is/upplysingar/jofnunarsaeti/|publisher=Kosningavefur Dómsmála- og Mannréttindaráðuneytisins|date=27 April 2013|access-date=30 October 2017|archive-date=2 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171102015341/http://www.kosning.is/upplysingar/jofnunarsaeti/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: Per Article 23 in Chapter V of Act No. 112 from the 25 June 2021 Elections Law, elections must be held no later than the same weekday of the month four years after the previous elections, counting from the turn of the month; therefore, because the 2021 Icelandic parliamentary election|2021 election took place on the fourth Saturday in September, the latest possible date for the election was 27 September 2025.{{cn|date=December 2024}}

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |title=112/2021: Kosningalög |url=https://www.althingi.is/lagas/nuna/2021112.html |access-date=28 May 2022 |publisher=Alþingi |archive-date=28 May 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220528200058/https://www.althingi.is/lagas/nuna/2021112.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Results showed no party winning a majority in the Althing, with the Social Democratic Alliance outperforming the ruling Independence Party (Iceland)|Independence Party to win a plurality of seats. The election saw the worst performance by the Independence Party (Iceland)|Independence Party, Progressive Party (Iceland)|Progressive Party, the Left-Green Movement, and the Pirate Party (Iceland)|Pirate Party in each of the parties' histories, while Viðreisn, the People's Party (Iceland)|People's Party, and the Centre Party (Iceland)|Centre Party saw their best performance in each of the parties' histories. This follows a trend of Icelanders voting against every post Great Recession|2008 recession government except for 2021 Icelandic parliamentary election|2021.

sentences.text:
{{Main|Cabinet of Kristrún Frostadóttir}}
People's Party (Iceland)|People's Party leader Inga Sæland expressed an interest in joining a governing coalition and said she favored a coalition consisting of her own party, the Social Democratic Alliance, and Viðreisn. However, she did not explicitly rule out any party. This followed with praise from the leader of the Social Democratic Alliance Kristrún Frostadóttir for Inga's work on repairing issues affecting the elderly and disabled.

references.text: <ref name=coalition>{{Cite news|date=2024-12-01 |access-date=2024-12-02|title=Inga Sæland hallar sér upp að Kristrúnu|url=https://www.mbl.is/frettir/innlent/2024/12/01/inga_saeland_hallar_ser_upp_ad_kristrunu/|website=mbl.is}}</ref>

sentences.text: Centre Party leader Sigmundur Davíð Gunnlaugsson met with President Halla Tómasdóttir on 2 December. He stated that he believed that Social Democratic Alliance leader Kristrún Frostadóttir should get the first mandate to form a government, as her party won first and said he did not rule out joining a government with any party. He stated he would implement "real changes", if he does enter a coalition. Independence Party leader and Prime Minister Bjarni Benediktsson (born 1970)|Bjarni Benediktsson also met with Halla and stated that he would not be making any special effort in asking for a mandate to forming a government, stating nothing was achieved in getting it and not being able to do anything with it, if received. He also stated he intended to meet with his party to decide on how to proceed, following the elections.

references.text: <ref name=MCentre>{{Cite news|date=2 Dec 2024 |access-date=2024-12-02|title=Eðlilegt að Kristrún fái umboðið|url= https://www.mbl.is/frettir/innlent/2024/12/02/edlilegt_ad_kristrun_fai_umbodid/|website=mbl.is}}</ref>

<ref name=DIndependence>{{Cite news|date=2 Dec 2024 |access-date=2024-12-02|title= Discussed the possibilities in the situation|url= https://icelandmonitor.mbl.is/news/news/2024/12/02/discussed_the_possibilities_in_the_situation/ |website=mbl.is}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 3 December, Halla gave Kristrún the first mandate and expressed interest in trying to form a government with her own party, Viðreisn, and the People's Party. On 4 December, Kristrún Frostadóttir began the formal process of forming a government consisting of Social Democratic Alliance, Viðreisn and the People's Party. If successfully formed, the government would have 36 of the 63 seats in the Althing. The coalition leaders were dubbed as "valkyries", citing that the three parties are led by women.

references.text: <ref name=SDGov>{{Cite news|date=3 Dec 2024 |access-date=2024-12-03|title= Kristrún Frostadóttir Receives The Mandate To Form Government|url= https://grapevine.is/news/2024/12/03/kristrun-frostadottir-receives-the-mandate-to-form-government/ |website=grapevine.is}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-12-04 |title=From Iceland — Kristrún Frostadóttir Begins Formal Government Formation |url=https://grapevine.is/news/2024/12/04/kristrun-frostadottir-begins-formal-government-formation/ |access-date=2024-12-04 |website=The Reykjavik Grapevine |language=en-US}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-12-03 |title=Valkyrie Coalition: Iceland's New Political Era |url=https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3179905-valkyrie-coalition-icelands-new-political-era?amp |access-date=2024-12-17 |website=www.devdiscourse.com |language=en-US}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 21 December, Kristrún Frostadóttir formed Cabinet of Kristrún Frostadóttir|her cabinet and was appointed prime minister. The cabinet consists of four ministers from Kristrún's Social Democratic Alliance, four from Þorgerður's Viðreisn, and three from Inga's People's Party.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |url=https://icelandmonitor.mbl.is/news/news/2024/12/21/these_are_the_ministers_of_the_government/ |title=These are the ministers of the government |language=en |website=Iceland Monitor.is |author=Iceland Monitor|access-date=21 December 2024}}</ref>
